title: Default math operators
description: All generic math operations like addition, multiplication, division subtraction and power are implemented in natural syntax and respect order of operations.

title: Selecting and advanced operations
description:
Every group of any equation can be selected at any point to highlight it and trigger further actions. Every kind of operator has a distinct set of possible actions.
Try experimenting with the actions. Here the "Show Export Structure" was used.
This one is particularly interesting in finding out how the system stores and represents the input.

title: Advanced Navigation
description:
For easier selection you do not always need to click operators in the gui.
 You can use the helper buttons "Sel. Parent","Sel. First Child","Sel. Next Sibling","Sel. Previous Sibling"
They all do what they say.
The buttons are also mapped to the 4 arrow keys. (Caution, arrow keys only work, just an operator has been clicked. They stop working as soon as the focus is shifted somewhere else.)

title: Implied Multiplication
description:
Multiplication will be implied between most operations. Operator precedence is taken into account when implying.
Some other operations may also be implied, for example here a - in a sum implies the + operation (however this can be overwritten by explicitly setting the *).

title: Advanced mathematical functions
description:
Functions with a more complex syntax, (that for example require more than one argument in front or behind) can be written with the "function(...arguments;)" syntax.
 The ";"-sign can be used at any time to delimit arguments structurally (and may be necessary in function arguments).

storage.bc264306-c6e3-40bb-8b5e-f2016a2cba7c: {"textValue":"sum(s1; s2; s3) ; int(i1; i2; i3; i4) ; exp(a) ; func(f; x) ; funcrm(f; x) ; sin(x) ; cos(x)"}

title: Single argument functions
description: If a function takes only one argument, automatic bracket-wrapping is implied.

storage.5395084d-43d4-4c3b-b47d-a8f0ec004093: {"textValue":"exp(x y z) = exp(x * y * z) = exp((x*y*z))"}

title: Structural operators
description:
There exist a set of structural symbols. Their use may result in the creation of a "structural_container".
These are always used to store elements that do not fit into a common operator-tree.
Structural containers can be created at will, using the ";"-sign.
The "{}"-sign allows to provide an empty argument if required arguments need to be left empty.

storage.2e4eb9d7-9237-446f-9917-5ba2d9f5eb3f: {"textValue":"x/y <=> x/y = x/y != sum({} {} {}) ; x/y < x/y > x/y <= x/y >= x/y"}

title: Constants
description:
Several constants are pre-provided.
Calling "Fold Numbers" on them will result in them presenting their values.

storage.efc3f7c6-9008-42be-bb4a-65518ebd79ee: {"textValue":"pi ; inf ; e ; i ; sqrt2 ; psi ; phi"}

title: Variables - Definition and Usage
description:
When Variables are typed, they can be accessed at the bottom of the page (for space-reasons only displayed in this example)
In the example the operations "Define Variable", "Unpack", "Define Variable", "Fold Numbers" have been used.
(Fold Numbers and number based operations remain working, no matter how deep nested variables are.)
Recursive or self-referencing variables break everything currently, so do not do it, I guess.

title: User-defined Macros utility
description:
Alongside the dynamic variables, there exists the possibility to define custom macros.
These basically work like the pre-defined functions.
 They may have arguments or not. The argument number is controlled by the largest number next to a "#" in the "macro-output".
 The same argument ("#<ARGUMENTNUMBER>") can be used multiple times in the output, in that case only the first instance is clickable.
The smallest argument-number is #0 (so if your macro contains a #1, it requires at least two arguments/parameters).

title: Bra-Ket with orthonormal evaluation
description:
There are helpers for writing in the physical Bra-c-ket notation.
"MergeAndEvaluateBraKet" may be used to check for orthonormal overlap.
For selection the "Sel. Parent" button may be helpful.

storage.111aaf5f-eb11-4eb6-8737-fcc57342b09c: {"textValue":"bra(up up up) ket(up down up) ; bracket((up ;down; up);H;(up ;down; up))"}

title: Fermionic- and Bosonic- Creation- and Annihilation-Operators
description:
As an example for non-commutative operators, these operators are implemented.
Evaluating such "Commutation-Relations" was the initial reason this tool was developed.
In this example, the "Commute with Subsequent" operation was applied.

title: Operator string ordering (works for non-commutative operators)
description:
This demonstrated the "Order Operator Strings" Functionality.
A full ordering can be performed even if operators are non-commutative (deals with - and possible additional terms).

title: Complex Numbers
description:
Complex numbers can be accessed through the complex unit "i", as well as the "complex" helper.
In this example the "MultiplyComplexNumbers" function was used to calculate the total product.

title: Distribute and cancel from sums
description:
The handy "Distribute" function can be used to expand products of sums.
After the terms have been fully expanded, the "EliminateCancelingTerms" function of sums is kicked into action.
In this case "Order Operator Strings" needed to be executed twice manually (the author of the tool mainly uses it for non-commutative operators, so ordering per default is not such a clean idea).

title: LaTeX
description:
As the tool uses LaTeX under the hood, generally all normal LaTeX commands should be additionally working.
There may be conflicts with the operator parsing in some cases, but I hope I didn't break anything important.
You may need to sprinkle some ";" and "{}" to force the parser into submission. If something is majorly broken, feel free to open an issue.
Because the "(" and ")" symbols perform a custom role in the parser, you can not use these when writing custom latex. But this environment provides the custom "\lbracket" and "\rbracket" macros.

title: Custom LaTeX macros
description:
If you want to use any of the math symbols that are processed by the parser when writing raw LaTeX, you may use the provided replacement macros.
Caution. If you export the LaTeX code into an external project of yours after using these, you need to define the macros in your Preamble or it won't work there.

title: Commutators
description: Support for commutator and anti-commutator helpers.
